page.title: 16YOXALL_ECOLOGY
page.content: The area is lowland pasture,rising to the east,with hedgerows,pockets of woodland and small ponds.It is crossed by the rivers Swarbourn and Trent.The few footpaths are maintained and marked.Conservation is aided by little use of the land for agriculture. Foxes stoats,weasels and frogs are common. A large rookery has 120 pairs.Rarities are 2 pairs of redshanks,2 pairs of kingfishers and 5 pairs of curlews. Orange hawkweed is only found in the churchyard;coralroot and orange balsam are only in 2 isolated locations; primrose and cowslip are rare.There are oak,ash,lime,beech,alder and sycamore trees.Elm is rare because of Dutch elm disease.Hedgerows contain hawthorn,blackthorn,elder,holly and field maple.The climate is temperate with average rainfall and frequent mist.Flooding occurs occasionally.
